Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity for Disciplinary Experts in Math and Science Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the Nation's growing need to recruit, prepare, and provide effective induction support for new STEM middle and high school teachers with degrees in STEM fields and strong content-specific pedagogical preparation. In particular the project will create an innovative pathway to teaching in Washington, DC for STEM professionals and STEM majors. This population represents an untapped supply of future teachers committed to teaching in high needs schools. Upon completion, the project will have validated a strategy to tap into this pool of STEM disciplinary experts, and will design and pilot a comprehensive set of learning experiences tailored to them. The project work will feature education and STEM faculty working with expert mathematics and science teachers in developing and piloting new methods to support teacher candidate development. Museum internships will be established and infused throughout the program, because museums are places in the urban landscape where teacher candidates can participate in authentic learning experiences and practice teaching a diverse population of students.

The long-term goal of this collaborative effort is to greatly enhance the DC area's ability to prepare "disciplinary experts" for urban mathematics and science teaching. There are three project outcomes. First, the project will discover how to increase the number of STEM professionals and undergraduate STEM majors preparing to teach in the DC area. Second, the project will institutionalize a sustainable nexus of collaboration among George Washington University's (GWU) education and STEM faculty, the District of Columbia Public and Public Charter Schools, the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, Carnegie Academy for Science Education, and GWU's Center for Civic Engagement, to improve the mathematics and science teacher education pipeline in Washington, DC. Third, a robust program of study will be produced featuring redesigned teacher preparation coursework, integrated and innovative field experiences, and early career mentoring. A systematic analysis of pilot data collected from selected student work and video from courses and field placements will facilitate the development of new curriculum emphasizing methods that teach candidates to use their knowledge in mathematics and science, not just to judge student reasoning, but to recognize and use school age students' good thinking (i.e. good scientific and mathematical ideas) as building blocks for learning. Finally, the project is designed to respond to the need to extend the scope of teacher training beyond what is traditionally done within the boundary of a university-based teacher education program, and therefore will also produce a specialized induction and early career support strategy that will link candidates with mentors who will follow them in their early years of teaching in the Washington, DC metropolitan area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building Capacity for Disciplinary Experts in Math and Science Teaching

This capacity building project catalyzed change in math and science teacher education at George Washington University (GWU). The collaboration among District of Columbia Public Schools Office of STEM Education, the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (NMNH), the Carnegie Academy for Science Education, GW faculty, the Nashman Center for Civic Engagement and the Center for Academic Planning and Assessment at GWU transformed GW’s traditional classroom-intensive graduate Master of Education (M.Ed.) program option into a contemporary student- and community-centered graduate curriculum for today’s STEM professionals.

The project’s intellectual products and outcomes include: new and revised M. Ed. courses aligned with both the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and the Common Core Math Standards (CCMS); video cases documenting collaborative teaching and problem solving aimed at developing pedagogical knowledge for teaching practices; an expanded pre-service practicum including both in-school and out-of-school field experiences; a more focused and data-driven approach for placing students in teaching internships using partner schools; and, a plan for induction year support and graduate tracking that uses an alumni survey and database built through the project. These products can be found on the project’s website at http://blogs.gwu.edu/teachstem/

The results of the collaborations of STEM education and STEM faculty, and the pre-service teacher education experiences in the Q?rius space at the NMNH are both of significant merit. These facets of the project were planned as research and development tasks, and as such resulted in curriculum products and rich data and new tools. Data from the teaching collaboration show the potential in developing math- and science-specific pedagogies in interdisciplinary teacher education courses. Our data also show that the interactive museum collaboration not only provided training to future teachers on how to use museum collections, but it also produced evidence that pre-service teachers experience multiple opportunities to practice important teaching skills such as facilitating and sustaining micro-inquiries with individuals and small groups; specifically demonstrating attending to learner thinking, asking generative questions, and sustaining engagement with artifacts. We can now show that a shared model for math and science teaching that is engaging for students and authentic to the work in the field(s) can provide anchors for discourse about a math and science content and practices (i.e., how we learn them and how to teach them).

The project’s work directly touched ten future science and math teachers, two STEM faculty members, two education faculty members, as well as several key partners. Our model of museum-based field experiences was shared at the DC STEM Network Summit to an audience of teachers, teacher educators, and out-of-school STEM providers, and other stakeholders, and will be the focus of a forthcoming book chapter in STEM education. An initial version of our video case study from the science methods course was shared at the National Association for Research in Science Teaching in 2015, reaching an audience of teacher educators and science education researchers, and was featured again at the 2016 Noyce Summit Poster Session. In addition, the nexus of collaboration formed by the project has since leveraged some of the ideas and relationships to facilitate an entirely new undergraduate minor in STEM teaching at GW. The impact of the new M.Ed. curriculum combined with the minor initiative, GW Teach, effectively doubles the number of future math and science teachers in the GWU pipeline from the time the project began.
